abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the West Africa Pilot
            Community-Based Natural Resources and Wildlife Management
            Project for Burkina Faso and Cote d'Ivoire were as
            follows: the outcome was unsatisfactory, the sustainability
            was unlikely, the institutional development impact was
            modest, the Bank performance was unsatisfactory, and
            borrower performance was satisfactory. Lessons learned:
            Community-Based Natural Resource and Wildlife Management
            Project (GEPRENAF's) success in bringing about policy
            changes in the management of natural resources demonstrates
            that a few carefully calculated risks can produce valuable
            results. In approaches such as GEPRENAF's that rely on
            sustaining community commitment to conservation and
            sustainable use of wild resources through the
            materialization of future economic benefits, the design
            should err on the side of caution. In both countries, the
            AGEREFs and the inter-village development committees favored
            local development activities over conservation work. The
            GEPRENAF approach tested a model that fully empowers
            communities. Modern wildlife management is a complex and
            highly technical operation that should be conducted by
            trained, experienced professionals, and not by amateurs. The
            project signed several protocols with government agencies
            and NGOs for the provision of technical services.
